history.content: Yes, at most 2 classes can be used for overlap. Double-majoring between related fields isn't easier than double-majoring between unrelated fields (which seems plausibly like a deliberate design decision).

children.subject:
Yeah, that post's tone was stronger than I really intended; should have hedged more. "easier to complete" is more of what I was going for.

I'm going to (perhaps unfairly) exclude 1A / 1B, since most students waive those requirements anyway. (Admittedly, I just forgot about lower-divs. But different departments vary so much in how many lower-div requirements they have anyway; I've seen as low as 0 (linguistics) and as high as 8 (compsci) within my own majors.)

And the point I meant to imply was that, for the L&S seven-breadth requirements, an unrelated major can often cover an additional two requirements that the first major can't (which is nicely symmetric with the limitation of two overlapping courses between majors).

I think that how much the conceptual similarity helps would vary be student; having similar classes can certainly help within those courses, but it might also burn someone out with too-similar material. But on average, I would expect it to help, yes.
That's a very good point about the seven course breadth, and I definitely see how different majors could help against burnout vs two heavy technical.

"Double-majoring between related fields isn't easier than double-majoring between unrelated fields"

Are you sure? Usually lower divs overlap quite a bit for related fields and then you can overlap two upper divs! That's 2-5+ less courses! Stats & CS you can overlap 5 courses, Math & Stats: 6, etc. I think that makes it quite a bit easier, plus related major's classes are more likely to help. Like cs70 helping for stat 134 or cs61a/b helping for stat 133.

history.content: You could not use 2 stats courses for your CS tech elective and 3 CS courses for your stats major cluster unless you took extra non-required courses in those departments.

If CS requires 7 units UD tech electives, and Stats requires 3 applied cluster courses, do I still have to worry about these ~5 classes if I do the double major? I was hoping I didn't have to but then I read that only two classes can be used for overlap, which seems pretty rough. So that means I would have to take 3 more classes than I expected? Is that how it works?
history.subject: Question about overlap for Stat/CS double major
